utterances: I mean, they keep on calling these terrorists faithless actors, faithless actors.
But they are operating from within your ground.
You've got to have some kind of control over them, and I don't think any kind of diplomatic pressure is working here.

So, I mean, I'm no big fan of war, but I think there has to be some military action taken by India with the help - with the support of the international community to teach Pakistan some kind of lesson.
Let's get a quick response from Somini Sengupta.
There are going to be a lot of people who feel the same way as Jependra.
Well, my intended answer was alien.
You remove the A, you get lien.
There were some interesting alternative answers--amore if you accept that Italian-English word to make more; agape (pronounced ah-GA-pay), which is love of God.
Agape (pronounced ah-ga-pay), uh-huh.
Exactly.
And areal--A-R-E-A-L--as in relating to area, makes real if you get rid of the A.
So we accepted all of those answers.
Don't you love it when you get all kinds of alternatives and ones you hadn't thought of before?
Were you guys aware of male haploidy?

Well, yes, perhaps there are, but there are also a lot of people in India, including the government, who realize - who have told me that there're certain difficulties (Laughing) involved in a military action, namely swift retaliation, which will come very, very quickly to India, which is (Laughing) a lot closer than Cincinnati.
So, people inside India stand to lose a lot.
In addition, the Indian government, remember, after another heinous attack on the Indian parliament in December 2001, did mobilize troops on the border, kept them there for almost a year.
There was a lot of talk and threat of a military conflict between India and Pakistan.
And then that ended.

You know, many Indian officials and strategic analysts point out that after that effort, India did not achieve what it had wanted to, which is an end to attacks on Indian soil that India believes originated from Pakistan.
So, that effort at threatening war seven years ago has not yielded the Indian government what it has wanted.
Somini Sengupta, thank you very much for your time.
Thank you.
Somini Sengupta, New York Times South Asia bureau chief.
Her piece, ""Dossier Gives Details on Mumbai Attacks,"" appears in today's edition.
She joined us on the phone from India.
You're listening to Talk of the Nation from NPR News.
Over the past week of fighting in the Middle East, the Israeli's targeted a relay station for Hezbollah's Al-Manar television channel.
The missile missed the station, Al-Manar remains on the air.
To find out the reach and content of Al-Manar, we're joined, from San Francisco, by Jamal Dajani.
He's director of Middle Eastern programming for Mosaic, a group that monitors media from that region.
Mr. Dajani was there any damage at all to the, the ability of Al-Manar to broadcast?
Well you know, initially they targeted the building and then they hit the top floor, so they kept broadcasting.
But now the entire building has been damaged and Al- Manar went off the air for about six hours.
I believe they have been broadcasting, which they are broadcasting, but they have been broadcasting from a van.
A van just moving around the city, possibly?
Just moving around, because they went back on the air right after six hours.
The entire building is, is hit as well as another building they have for another station, called Al-Nour TV, that has been totally destroyed.
And who is watching this channel and, and, and how large would the audience be do you think?
This signal?
Well I mean, you know in the Middle East, you have two hundred plus different satellite channels and the advantage of having satellite TV there - that you cover the entire region.
So all these channels, in Lebanon alone, six different satellite channels and Al-Manar has a large audience.
The large audience is comprised of Islamists, and people that don't believe their own government, or they have a, a Shiite population following.
So it is a very popular channel.
After Al-Jazeera and Al Arabiya, and perhaps Abu Dhabi TV, Al- Manar could be anywhere between fifth and seventh you know between that that ranking in the entire region.
If somebody just watches Al-Manar, is there any truth there, or is it purely inflammatory propaganda?
They have their own slant on things, but you know who is not slanted in the Middle East?
I mean it's really it's really difficult to talk about the war of information or the propaganda war, you know.
The United States also have Al- Hurra station operating there and, and people view Al-Hurra which means right out of Virginia.
A lot of people look at it there as an American propaganda tool.
The Israeli's they have their own Arabic speaking station.

Iran also joins the mix, they have another station called Al-Haram, now BBC has Arabic, so you know, there is a whole sea of competition going on there and I would say every single station has its own agenda.
Jamal Dajani from the media monitoring group Mosaic, thank you sir.
Thank you.

Legislative approvals for which I'm given no credit in the mainstream media - we have - I believe it's 88, which is number one in the history of our country.
Second now is Harry Truman.
Harry Truman had more legislative approvals than any other president.
Tam, President Trump makes a lot of claims there.
Can you give us a quick fact check?
Gladly.
So in a rare occurrence, Trump is actually selling himself short.
He signed 96 bills into law this year, not 88.
As for beating Truman, he's not even close.
Trump actually trails all of his recent predecessors in the number of bills signed.
And the Truman Library gives a rough estimate of about 240 to 250 bills signed in his first year, so Trump is trailing by a lot.
Does the White House explain that gap between pretty easily documented record and the president's claim of numbers?
I actually went to them and said, what is this Truman claim because it doesn't seem to match up?
And they never responded.
But you know, it's important to say that tallying bills is...
Yeah.
...A truly terrible way to measure accomplishment.
Political scientists will say look at significance instead.
That's a much better measure.
Well, let's do that.
There are bills, and there are bills.
Of those 96 bills that President Trump signed, how many could be called truly significant?
Checks and balances lead to oversight investigations.
